Donoghue v. Stevenson, [1932] A.C. 562 (.raw_text: Donoghue v. Stevenson, [1932] A.C. 562 (establishing foundational duty principles in negligence);
Donoghue v. Stevenson, [1932] A.C. 562 (.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, motorists have a duty to act reasonably and to avoid creating foreseeable risk of harm to persons using public ways.

Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928) (duty and foreseeability);
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, motorists have a duty to act reasonably and to avoid creating foreseeable risk of harm to persons using public ways.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the scope of a Massachusetts motorist’s duty on public ways. Palsgraf is a New York Court of Appeals decision about general negligence duty and foreseeability, in the context of railroad guards and a passenger on a platform, not motorists or Massachusetts law. While it articulates a general foreseeability-based duty principle, it does not address or establish the specific rule that Massachusetts imposes on motorists using public ways, so it cannot be cited as direct authority for that proposition of Massachusetts law.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..relevant_excerpt: “The risk reasonably to be perceived defines the duty to be obeyed, and risk imports relation; it is risk to another or to others within the range of apprehension… Negligence is not actionable unless it involves the invasion of a legally protected interest, the violation of a right.”

Commonwealth v. Searles;.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that drivers owe duties to other road users and may be liable for negligent operation of vehicles.
